Award.AbstractNarration:
Signal processing methods for passive acoustic monitoring of marine mammals
Eva-Marie Nosal (PI) and Anders Host-Madsen (co-PI)

The welfare of the marine environment is of increasing global concern. Underwater acoustics is a promising approach to assess and mitigate human impact on marine mammals, as well as to determine population sizes, monitor behavior and migration patterns, identify critical habitat, and study bioacoustics. The research funded by this award is expected to lead to radically improved methods for passive acoustic monitoring of marine animals by using modern signal processing methods. Passive acoustic monitoring methods are non-invasive, unobtrusive, and can be used in poor weather conditions and lack of daylight. They enable continuous and remote sensing in a cost and time efficient manner. For these reasons, passive acoustic techniques are valuable on their own, and as a complement to existing visual and tagging techniques for studying marine mammals.

Many marine mammals are vocal so by processing data collected by hydrophones (underwater microphones), they can be detected, monitored and studied. Due to the complex nature of the marine environment and the vocalizations, advanced signal processing methods are needed. The project will consider the following specific problems 1) Channel estimation and use of this for localization of mammals. 2) Separation of multiple mammals. Signal processing methods for blind source separation can be used to separate the vocalizations of multiple mammals within the range of the hydrophones. 3) Detection of vocalizations. Most of the time sound recordings are pure noise. The project will develop methods for separating noise and signal segments. 4) Analysis of vocalizations. The project will then look into further analyzing the sounds, for example for classification of species, establishing information content in vocalizations, and extracting bioacoustic properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studying marine mammal behavior and physiology is complicated by the fact that they spend most of their lives underwater. The standard techniques for studies, censusing, and detection of marine mammals are visual surveys conducted from boats or shore-stations and bioacoustic tags that are attached to animals. Since many marine mammals are highly vocal, and since sound propagates over long distances in the ocean, passive acoustic monitoring (PAM) techniques are third method to study marine mammals. In PAM, one or more hydrophones are towed behind a ship or deployed in a fixed bottom-mounted or suspended array. Animal calls are recorded and processed to provide information on animal presence, species, and location. PAM is useful on its own for census efforts and behavioral studies, particularly for continuous, long-term monitoring and in difficult or inaccessible areas. PAM can also be used for bioacoustics research on free-ranging animals. For these reasons, PAM is a powerful tool to help determine population sizes and trends, monitor behavior and migration patterns, identify critical habitat, and so forth; knowledge and understanding is critical to conservation efforts. The main goal of this project was to develop new signal processing methods for PAM that are based on recent advances in signal processing methodology.

 

The first specific area that was developed in this project was a blind channel estimation (BCE) method for the underwater acoustic environment. In the raw recording of a marine mammal call, we can’t tell what sound the animal originally made because the sound is changed as it travels from the animal to the hydrophone (just as your voice sounds different in a small room than it does outside). BCE is a way of separating the call from the environment, which leaves us with information about the call itself and about the environment that it traveled through. The development of BCE dates back to the 1970s to improve wireless communication fidelity in time-varying environments (e.g., cell phone communication while traveling through urban canyons). The specifics of our problem (whale calls in and underwater environment) are very different from the original problem, which required that we modify existing BCE methods to be able to apply them. We implemented, modified and tested 6 BCE optimization methods before finally finding one (called NESTA) that was useful, with some modification, for underwater acoustics. We applied our BCE NESTA method to simulated data, controlled test recordings, and recordings of humpback whales in Hawaii.

 

The second area that was developed as part of this project was source separation techniques for multiple animals. When multiple mammals are within the detection range of a hydrophone, their sounds are mixed together and we cannot tell which sound goes with which animal. This is similar to the classical cocktail party problem: In a loud party, how can you discern the words of the person talking to you? This is a well-studied area in signal processing as there any many problems where the input signals need to be “blindly” recovered from the outputs of an unknown mixing system. We were especially interested in the blind source separation (BSS) which originated in the 1980s in vertebrate motion decoding. That is, can the movement in a joint be predicted by the rate at which the neurons fire? While the BSS field is quite mature, the application to marine mammal vocalizations is not. It would be ideal to have one algorithm that would separate all marine mammal calls but since types of vocalizations varied greatly and it is instead necessary to aggregate a suite of algorithms to handle all situations more completely.
